docs.abstract: New rules are aimed at controlling the way Chinese Internet users post messages on social networking sites that have posed challenges to the Chinese Communist Party.

headline.main: Beijing Imposes New Rules on Social Networking Sites

docs.snippet: New rules are aimed at controlling the way Chinese Internet users post messages on social networking sites that have posed challenges to the Chinese Communist Party.
docs.lead_paragraph: Officials announced new rules on Friday aimed at controlling the way Chinese Internet users post messages on social networking sites that have posed challenges to the Chinese Communist Party's propaganda machinery, reports Edward Wong from Beijing. For many users, the most striking of the new rules requires people using the sites, called microblogs, or weibo in Chinese, to register with their real names and biographical information. Read the entire article in The New York Times.

docs.abstract: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda arrives in China for state visit that was originally aimed at improving bilateral ties, but is now expected to focus on the uncertainty over North Korea's intentions after the death of Kim Jong-il. Photo (M).

headline.main: Japan and China Focus on North Korea

docs.snippet: Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda of Japan arrived in Beijing for a two-day state visit that is expected to focus on the uncertainty over North Korea’s intentions after the death of Kim Jong-il.
docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda of Japan arrived in Beijing on Sunday for a two-day state visit that was originally aimed at improving bilateral ties, but is now expected to focus on the uncertainty over North Korea's intentions after the death of Kim Jong-il. Speaking before he left Tokyo, Mr. Noda told reporters that he planned ''to exchange views and information in detail so as to avert a harmful effect on peace and stability on the Korean Peninsula.''
